revision.comment: /* Cratering */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Meteoritics &Planetary Science → Meteoritics & Planetary Science
revision.text:
{{short description|Similarities and differences between planets}} '''Comparative planetary science''' or '''comparative planetology''' is a branch of [[Outline of space science|space science]] and [[planetary science]] in which different natural processes and systems are studied by their effects and phenomena on and between multiple [[Astronomical object|bodies]]. The planetary processes in question include geology, hydrology, atmospheric physics, and interactions such as impact cratering, space weathering, and magnetospheric physics in the solar wind, and possibly biology, via [[astrobiology]].
Comparison of multiple bodies assists the researcher, if for no other reason than the Earth is far more accessible than any other body. Those distant bodies may then be evaluated in the context of processes already characterized on Earth. Conversely, other bodies (including [[Planetary system|extrasolar ones]]) may provide additional examples, edge cases, and counterexamples to earthbound processes; without a greater context, studying these phenomena in relation to Earth alone may result in low sample sizes and observational biases.
==Background==
The term "comparative planetology" was coined by [[George Gamow]], who reasoned that to fully understand our own planet, we must study others. [[Arie Poldervaart|Poldervaart]] focused on the Moon, stating "An adequate picture of this original planet and its development to the present earth is of great significance, is in fact the ultimate goal of geology as the science leading to knowledge and understanding of earth's history."<ref name="lowman">{{cite book |last=Lowman |first=P. |title=Exploring Space, Exploring Earth: New Understanding of the Earth from Space Research |date=15 August 2002|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|location=Cambridge, UK|isbn=978-0-521-89062-5|chapter=6.1}}</ref>
==Geology and geochemistry==
All terrestrial planets (and some satellites, such as the Moon) are essentially composed of [[silicates]] wrapped around iron cores.<ref name=lowman /><ref name=murray /> The large outer Solar System moons and Pluto have more ice, and less rock and metal, but still undergo analogous processes.
===Volcanism===
{{main|Volcanism}}
Volcanism on Earth is largely [[lava]]-based. Other terrestrial planets display volcanic features assumed to be lava-based, evaluated in the context of analogues readily studied on Earth. For example, Jupiter's moon [[Volanism of Io|Io displays extant volcanism]], including lava flows. These flows were initially inferred to be composed mostly of various [[Allotropes of sulfur|forms of molten elemental sulfur]], based on analysis of imaging done by the [[Voyager program|''Voyager'' probes]].<ref name="Sagan1979">{{cite journal |title=Sulphur flows on Io |journal=Nature |last=Sagan |first=C. |pages=750–53 |volume=280 |issue= 5725|date=1979 |doi=10.1038/280750a0|bibcode = 1979Natur.280..750S }}</ref> However, Earth-based infrared studies done in the 1980s and 1990s caused the consensus to shift in favor of a primarily silicate-based model, with sulfur playing a secondary role.<ref name="Spencer1996">{{cite journal |title=Io on the Eve of the Galileo Mission |journal=[[Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences]] |last=Spencer |first=J. R. |author2=Schneider, N. M. |pages=125–90 |volume=24 |date=1996 |doi=10.1146/annurev.earth.24.1.125|bibcode = 1996AREPS..24..125S }}</ref>
Much of the surface of [[Mars]] is composed of various [[basalt]]s considered analogous to Hawaiian basalts, by their [[Spectroscopy|spectra]] and ''in situ'' chemical analyses (including [[Martian meteorites]]).<ref>{{cite journal | author1=Chemtob, S. | author2=Jolliff, B. | title=Silica coatings in the Ka'u Desert, Hawaii, a Mars analog terrain: A micromorphological, spectral, chemical, and isotopic study |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Planets | volume=115 | issue=E4 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2009JE003473/full |date=1 April 2010 |display-authors=etal | doi=10.1029/2009JE003473 | bibcode=2010JGRE..115.4001C}}</ref><ref>[http://www.spacedaily.com/news/mars-mers-04zza.html]</ref> Mercury and Earth's Moon similarly feature [[Lunar mare|large areas of basalts]], formed by ancient volcanic processes. Surfaces in the polar regions show [[Patterned ground#Polygons|polygonal morphologies]], also seen on Earth.<ref>{{cite journal | author1=Levy, J. | author2=Marchant, D. | author3=Head, J. | title=Thermal contraction crack polygons on Mars: A synthesis from HiRISE, Phoenix, and terrestrial analog studies | journal=Icarus | volume=206 | issue=1 | date=12 September 2009 | doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2009.09.005 | bibcode=2010Icar..206..229L | pages=229–252}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Permafrost on Mars and Earth | url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/IPY/multimedia/ipyimg_20080528.html| accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref>
In addition to basalt flows, Venus is home to a large number of [[pancake dome]] volcanoes created by highly viscous silica-rich lava flows. These domes lack a known Earth analogue. They do bear some morphological resemblance to terrestrial rhyolite-dacite [[lava domes]], although the pancake domes are much flatter and uniformly round in nature.<ref name="PaterLissauer2014">{{cite book|last1=de Pater|first1=Imke |last2=Lissauer|first2=Jack J.|title=Planetary Sciences|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=stFpBgAAQBAJ|edition=2nd, revised|date=31 December 2014|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-316-19569-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=pancake dome: Venus | url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/media/3471/Volcanic-pancake-domes-in-the-elevated-region-Eistla-Regio-on | accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Unusual Volcanoes on Venus | url=http://volcano.oregonstate.edu/oldroot/volcanoes/planet_volcano/venus/unusual.html | accessdate= 26 April 2015}}</ref>
Certain regions further out in the Solar System exhibit [[cryovolcanism]], a process not seen anywhere on earth. Cryovolcanism is studied through laboratory experiments, conceptual and numerical modeling, and by cross-comparison to other examples in the field. Examples of bodies with cryovolcanic features include [[comet]]s, some [[asteroid]]s and [[Centaur (minor planet)|Centaurs]], [[Mars]], [[Europa (moon)|Europa]], [[Enceladus]], [[Triton (moon)|Triton]], and possibly [[Titan (moon)|Titan]], [[Ceres (dwarf planet)|Ceres]], [[Pluto]], and [[Eris (dwarf planet)|Eris]].
The trace dopants of Europa's ice are currently postulated to contain sulfur.<ref>{{cite web | title=NASA - Europa's Hidden Ice Chemistry | url=http://nasa.gov/topics/solarsystem/features/europa-ice.html | accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref> This is being evaluated via a Canadian sulfate spring as an analogue, in preparation for future Europa probes.<ref>{{cite web | title=NASA mission to Jupiter's moon Europa gets boost from Nunavut glacier | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/nasa-mission-to-jupiter-s-moon-europa-gets-boost-from-nunavut-glacier-1.2946908 | accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref> [[Small solar system bodies|Small bodies]] such as comets, some asteroid types, and dust grains, on the other hand, serve as counterexamples. Assumed to have experienced little or no heating, these materials may contain (or be) samples representing the early Solar System, which have since been erased from Earth or any other large body.
Some extrasolar planets are covered entirely in [[Lava planet|lava oceans]], and some are [[Tidal locking|tidally locked]] planets, whose star-facing hemisphere is entirely lava.
===Cratering===
{{main|Impact crater}}
The craters observed on the Moon were once assumed to be volcanic. Earth, by comparison, did not show a similar crater count, nor a high frequency of [[Bolide|large meteor events]], which would be expected as two nearby bodies should experience similar impact rates. Eventually this volcanism model was overturned, as numerous Earth craters (demonstrated by e. g., [[shatter cone]]s, [[shocked quartz]] and other [[impactite]]s, and possibly [[Tektite|spall]]) were found, after having been eroded over geologic time. Craters formed by larger and larger ordnance also served as models. The Moon, on the other hand, shows no atmosphere or hydrosphere, and could thus accumulate and preserve impact craters over billions of years despite a low impact rate at any one time. In addition, more searches by more groups with better equipment highlighted the great number of asteroids, presumed to have been even more numerous in earlier Solar System periods.<ref>{{cite book|last=Wilhelms|first=D.|title=To a Rocky Moon: A geologist's history of lunar exploration|publisher=University of Arizona Press|date=1993|chapter= 1-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Koerberl|first1=C|title=Craters on the Moon from Galileo to Wegener: A short history of the Impact Hypothesis and Implications for the Study of terrestrial Impact Craters|date=2000|publisher=Kluver}}</ref>
As on Earth, a low [[Crater counting|crater count]] on other bodies indicates young surfaces. This is particularly credible if nearby regions or bodies show heavier cratering. Young surfaces, in turn, indicate atmospheric, tectonic or volcanic, or hydrological processing on large bodies and comets, or dust redistribution or a relatively recent formation on asteroids (i. e., splitting from a parent body).<ref>{{cite web | title=Comparative Cratering Processes | url=https://solarsystem.nasa.gov/educ/docs/Comparative_Cratering_Processes.pdf | accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref>
Examination of the cratering record on multiple bodies, at multiple areas in the Solar System, points to a [[Late Heavy Bombardment]], which in turn gives evidence of the Solar System's early history. However, the Late Heavy Bombardment as currently proposed has some issues and is not completely accepted.<ref name=Hartmann_2003>{{cite journal|last=Hartmann|first=W. K.|title=Megaregolith evolution and cratering cataclysm models--Lunar cataclysm as a misconception (28 years later)|journal=Meteoritics & Planetary Science|date=2003|volume=38|issue=4|pages=579–593|doi=10.1111/j.1945-5100.2003.tb00028.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1945-5100.2003.tb00028.x/abstract|bibcode = 2003M&PS...38..579H }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author1=Arrhenius, G. | author2=Hill, J. | title=The Late Heavy Bombardment of the Moon – an Evolving Problem | journal=Astrobiology Science Conference 2010 | date=26 April 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=Dating Planetary Surfaces with Craters Why There Is No Crisis In Crater Count Dating | url=https://pseudoastro.wordpress.com/2008/10/21/dating-planetary-surfaces-with-craters-why-there-is-no-crisis-in-crater-count-dating/ | accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref>
One model for Mercury's exceptionally high density compared to other terrestrial planets<ref>{{cite web | title=Question 1: Why is Mercury so dense? - MESSENGER | url=http://messenger.jhuapl.edu/why_mercury/q1.html | accessdate=26 April 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904182638/http://messenger.jhuapl.edu/why_mercury/q1.html | archivedate=4 September 2014 | df= }}</ref> is the stripping off of a significant amount of crust and/or mantle from extremely heavy bombardment.<ref>{{cite web | title=Why Mercury is a hard orange, not a soft peach | url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn23534-why-mercury-is-a-hard-orange-not-a-soft-peach.html | accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.space.com/26447-mercury-composition-giant-impact.html |title=Did Huge Impact Shape Planet Mercury? |work=[[Space.com]] |date=6 July 2014 |author=Jesse Emspak |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150601202114/http://www.space.com/26447-mercury-composition-giant-impact.html |archivedate=1 June 2015 |dead-url=no |accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref>
===Differentiation===
{{main|Planetary differentiation}}
As a large body, Earth can efficiently retain its internal heat (from its [[Kelvin-Helmholtz mechanism|initial formation]] plus [[radioactive decay|decay]] of its [[radioisotopes]]) over the long timescale of the Solar System. It thus retains a molten [[Planetary core|core]], and has [[Planetary differentiation|differentiated]]- dense materials have sunk to the core, while light materials float to form a crust.
Other bodies, by comparison, may or may not have differentiated, based on their formation history, radioisotope content, further energy input via bombardment, distance from the Sun, size, etc. Studying bodies of various sizes and distances from the Sun provides examples and places constraints on the differentiation process. Differentiation itself is evaluated indirectly, by the mineralogy of a body's surface, versus its expected bulk density and mineralogy, or via shape effects due to slight variations in gravity.<ref>{{cite journal | author1=Thomas, P., | author2=Parker, J. | title=Differentiation of the asteroid Ceres as revealed by its shape | journal=Nature | volume=437 | date=8 Sep 2005 |display-authors=etal | doi=10.1038/nature03938 | pages=224–226|bibcode = 2005Natur.437..224T | pmid=16148926}}</ref> Differentiation may also be measured directly, by the higher-order terms of a body's gravity field as measured by a [[Planetary flyby|flyby]] or [[gravitational assist]], and in some cases by [[libration]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | author1=Peale, S. | author2=Stanton, R. | title=A Procedure for Determining the Nature of Mercury's core | journal=Meteoritics & Planetary Science | volume=37 | pages=1269–1283 | date=2002 |bibcode = 2002M&PS...37.1269P |doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.2002.tb00895.x |display-authors=etal}}</ref>
Edge cases include Vesta and some of the larger moons, which show differentiation but are assumed to have since fully solidified. The question of whether Earth's Moon has solidified, or retains some molten layers, has not been definitively answered. Additionally, differentiation processes are expected to vary along a continuum. Bodies may be composed of lighter and heavier rocks and metals, a high water ice and volatiles content (with less mechanical strength) in cooler regions of the Solar System, or primarily ices with a low rock/metal content even farther from the Sun. This continuum is thought to record the varying chemistries of the early Solar System, with refractories surviving in warm regions, and volatiles driven outward by the young Sun.
The cores of planets are inaccessible, studied indirectly by seismometry, gravimetry, and in some cases magnetometry. However, iron and stony-iron meteorites are likely fragments from the cores of parent bodies which have partially or completely differentiated, then shattered. These meteorites are thus the only means of directly examining deep-interior materials and their processes.
[[Gas giant]] planets represent another form of differentiation, with multiple fluid layers by density. Some distinguish further between true gas giants, and [[ice giant]]s further from the Sun.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Boss, A. | title=Formation of gas and ice giant planets | journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters | volume=202 | pages=513–523 | date=30 September 2002 |bibcode = 2002E&PSL.202..513B |doi = 10.1016/S0012-821X(02)00808-7 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author1=Lambrechts, M. | author2=Johansen, A. | author3=Morbidelli, A. | title=Separating gas-giant and ice-giant planets by halting pebble accretion | journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics | volume=572 | date=25 Nov 2014 | doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201423814 | bibcode=2014A&A...572A..35L | pages=A35|arxiv = 1408.6087 }}</ref>
===Tectonics===
{{main|Tectonics}}
In turn, a molten core may allow plate tectonics, of which Earth shows major features. Mars, as a smaller body than Earth, shows no current tectonic activity, nor mountain ridges from geologically recent activity. This is assumed to be due to an interior that has cooled faster than the Earth (see geomagnetism below). An edge case may be Venus, which does not appear to have extant tectonics. However, in its history, it likely has had tectonic activity but lost it.<ref>{{cite journal | author1=Cherkashina, O. | author2=Guseva, E. | author3=Krassilnikov, A. | title=Mapping of Rift Zones on Venus, Preliminary Results: Spatial Distribution, Relationship with Regional Plains, Morphology of Fracturing, Topography and Style of Volcanism | journal=35th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference | date=15 Mar 2004 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://csep10.phys.utk.edu/astr161/lect/venus/surface.html | accessdate=26 Apr 2015 |title= The Surface Features of Venus}}</ref> It is possible tectonic activity on Venus may still be sufficient to restart after a long era of accumulation.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Solomon, S. | title=A Tectonic Resurfacing Model for Venus | journal=LPSC XXIV | date=1993 }}</ref>
Io, despite having high volcanism, does not show any tectonic activity, possibly due to sulfur-based magmas with higher temperatures, or simply higher volumetric fluxes.<ref>{{ cite book|last=Davies|first=A.|title=Volcanism on Io|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=292 }}</ref> Meanwhile, Vesta's [[fossa (geology)|fossae]] may be considered a form of tectonics, despite that body's small size and cool temperatures.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Buczowski|first1=D.|last2=Wyrick|first2=D.|last3=Iyer|first3=K.|last4=Kahn|first4=E.|last5=Scully|first5=J.|last6=Nathues|first6=A.|last7=Gaskell|first7=R.|last8=Roatsch|first8=T.|title=Large-scale troughs on Vesta: A signature of planetary tectonics|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|date=29 Sep 2012|volume=39|issue=18|page=205|display-authors=etal|doi=10.1029/2012gl052959|bibcode=2012GeoRL..3918205B}}</ref>
Europa is a key demonstration of outer-planet tectonics. Its surface shows [[Chaos terrain|movement of ice blocks or rafts]], [[Fault (geology)#Strike-slip faults|strike-slip faults]], and possibly [[diapirs]]. The question of extant tectonics is far less certain, possibly having been replaced by local cryomagmatism.<ref>{{ cite book|last1=Pappalardo|first1=R.|last2=McKinnon|first2=W.|last3=Khurana|first3=K., eds.|title=Europa }}</ref> Ganymede and Triton may contain tectonically or cryovolcanically resurfaced areas, and [[Miranda (moon)|Miranda's]] irregular terrains may be tectonic.
[[Earthquake]]s are well-studied on Earth, as multiple [[seismometer]]s or large arrays can be used to derive quake waveforms in multiple dimensions. The Moon is the only other body to successfully receive a seismometer array; "marsquakes" and the mars interior are based on simple models and Earth-derived assumptions. Venus has received negligible seismometry.
Gas giants may in turn show different forms of heat transfer and mixing.<ref>{{cite journal | author1=Li, C. | author2=Ingersoll, A. | title=Moist convection in hydrogen atmospheres and the frequency of Saturn’s giant storms | journal=Nature Geoscience | date=13 Apr 2015 | doi = 10.1038/ngeo2405 | volume=8 | pages=398–403|bibcode = 2015NatGe...8..398L }}</ref> Furthermore, gas giants show different heat effects by size and distance to the Sun. Uranus shows a net negative heat budget to space, but the others (including Neptune, farther out) are net positive.
===Geomagnetism===
{{main|Magnetosphere}}
Two terrestrial planets (Earth and Mercury) display magnetospheres, and thus have molten metal layers. Similarly, all four gas giants have magnetospheres, which indicate layers of conductive fluids. [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]] also shows a weak magnetosphere, taken as evidence of a subsurface layer of salt water, while the volume around [[Rhea (moon)|Rhea]] shows symmetrical effects which may be rings or a magnetic phenomenon. Of these, Earth's magnetosphere is by far the most accessible, including from the surface. It is therefore the most studied, and extraterrestrial magnetospheres are examined in light of prior Earth studies.
Still, differences exist between magnetospheres, pointing to areas needing further research. Jupiter's magnetosphere is stronger than the other gas giants, while Earth's is stronger than Mercury's. Mercury and Uranus have offset magnetospheres, which have no satisfactory explanation yet. Uranus' tipped axis causes its magnetotail to corkscrew behind the planet, with no known analogue. Future Uranian studies may show new magnetospheric phenomena.
Mars shows remnants of an earlier, planetary-scale magnetic field, with [[Plate tectonics#Magnetic striping|stripes as on Earth]]. This is taken as evidence that the planet had a molten metal core in its prior history, allowing both a magnetosphere and tectonic activity (as on Earth). Both of these have since dissipated. Earth's Moon shows localized magnetic fields, indicating some process other than a large, molten metal core. This may be the source of [[lunar swirl]]s, not seen on Earth.<ref>{{cite web | title=Magnetic And Spectral Properties Of Lunar Swirls, And A New Mechanism For Their Formation | url=http://www.planetology.ru/txt/garrickbethell_et_al_20091004_12411.pdf | accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref>
===Geochemistry===
{{main|Geochemistry}}
Apart from their distance to the Sun, different bodies show chemical variations indicating their formation and history. Neptune is denser than Uranus, taken as one piece of evidence that the two may have switched places in the early Solar System. Comets show both high volatile content, and grains containing refractory materials. This also indicates some mixing of materials through the Solar System when those comets formed. Mercury's inventory of materials by volatility is being used to evaluate different models for its formation and/or subsequent modification.
Isotopic abundances indicate processes over the history of the Solar System. To an extent, all bodies formed from the presolar nebula. Various subsequent processes then alter elemental and isotopic ratios. The gas giants in particular have enough gravity to retain primary atmospheres, taken largely from the presolar nebula, as opposed to the later outgassing and reactions of secondary atmospheres. Differences in gas giant atmospheres compared to solar abundances then indicate some process in that planet's history. Meanwhile, gases at small planets such as Venus and Mars have isotopic differences indicating [[atmospheric escape]] processes.{argon isotope ratio planet meteorite}{neon isotope ratio meteorite}
The various modifications of surface minerals, or [[space weathering]], is used to evaluate meteorite and asteroid types and ages. Rocks and metals shielded by atmospheres (particularly thick ones), or other minerals, experience less weathering and fewer [[ion implantation|implantation chemistries]] and [[cosmic ray track]]s. Asteroids are currently graded by their spectra, indicating surface properties and mineralogies. Some asteroids appear to have less space weathering, by various processes including a relatively recent formation date or a "freshening" event. As Earth's minerals are well shielded, space weathering is studied via extraterrestrial bodies, and preferably multiple examples.
[[Kuiper Belt Objects]] display very weathered or in some cases very fresh surfaces. As the long distances result in low spatial and spectral resolutions, KBO surface chemistries are currently evaluated via analogous moons and asteroids closer to Earth.
{{see also|Meteoritics}}
==Aeronomy and atmospheric physics== Earth's atmosphere is far thicker than that of Mars, while far thinner than Venus'. In turn, the envelopes of gas giants are a different class entirely, and show their own gradations. Meanwhile, smaller bodies show tenuous atmospheres ("surface-bound exospheres"), with the exception of Titan and arguably Triton. Comets vary between negligible atmospheres in the outer solar system, and active [[coma]]s millions of miles across at perihelion. Exoplanets may in turn possess atmospheric properties known and unknown in our star system.
===Aeronomy===
{{main|Aeronomy}}
[[Atmospheric escape]] is largely a thermal process. The atmosphere a body can retain therefore varies from the warmer inner Solar System, to the cooler outer regions. Different bodies in different Solar System regions provide analogous or contrasting examples. The atmosphere of Titan is considered analogous to an early, colder Earth; the atmosphere of Pluto is considered analogous to an enormous comet.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Greaves |first1=J. |last2=Helling |first2=C. |title=Discovery of carbon monoxide in the upper atmosphere of Pluto |doi=10.1111/j.1745-3933.2011.01052.x|arxiv=1104.3014 |bibcode=2011MNRAS.414L..36G }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Is Pluto a giant comet? |url=http://www.icq.eps.harvard.edu/ICQPluto.html |accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref>
The presence or absence of a magnetic field affects an upper atmosphere, and in turn the overall atmosphere. Impacts of [[solar wind]] particles create chemical reactions and ionic species, which may in turn affect magnetospheric phenomena. Earth serves as a counterexample to Venus and Mars, which have no planetary magnetospheres, and to Mercury, with a magnetosphere but negligible atmosphere.
Jupiter's moon Io creates sulfur emissions, and a [[Magnetosphere of Jupiter#Role of Io|feature of sulfur and some sodium]] around that planet. Similarly, Earth's Moon has [[Sodium tail of the Moon|trace sodium emissions, and a far weaker tail]]. Mercury also has a [[Atmosphere of Mercury|trace sodium atmosphere]].
Jupiter itself is assumed to have some characteristics of extrasolar [[Super-Jupiter|"super Jupiters"]] and [[Brown dwarf|brown dwarves]].
===Seasons===
Uranus, [[axial tilt|tipped]] on its side, is postulated to have [[Climate of Uranus#Seasonal variation|seasonal effects]] far stronger than on Earth. Similarly, Mars is postulated to have varied its [[axial tilt]] over eons, and to a far greater extent than on Earth. This is hypothesized to have dramatically altered not only seasons but climates on Mars, for which some evidence has been observed.<ref>{{cite web|title=NASA Orbiter Finds Martian Rock Record With 10 Beats to the Bar|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/MRO/news/mro-20081204.html|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref> Venus has negligible tilt, eliminating seasons, and a slow, retrograde rotation, causing different diurnal effects than on Earth and Mars.
===Clouds and haze layers===
From Earth, a [[Atmosphere of Venus|planetwide cloud layer]] is the dominant feature of Venus in the visible spectrum; this is also true of Titan. Venus' cloud layer is composed of sulfur dioxide particles, while Titan's is a [[Atmosphere of Titan|mixture of organics]].
The gas giant planets display clouds or belts of various compositions, including ammonia and methane.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Adumitroaie|first1=V|last2=Gulkis|first2=S|last3=Oyafuso|first3=F|title=Ammonia-water solution cloud modeling of gas giant planets via phase equilibrium calculations, in 2014 IEEE Aerospace Conference|date=2014|publisher=IEEE}}</ref>
===Circulation and winds===
Venus and Titan, and to a lesser extent Earth, are superrotators- the atmosphere turns about the planet faster than the surface beneath. While these atmospheres share physical processes, they exhibit diverse characteristics.<ref>{{cite web | title=Dynamics in planetary Atmospheric Physics: comparative studies of equatorial superrotation for Venus, Titan, and earth | url=http://www.bu.edu/csp/uv/cp-aeronomy/Zhu_2005.pdf | accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref>
[[Hadley cell]]s, first postulated and confirmed on Earth, are seen in different forms in other atmospheres. Earth has Hadley cells north and south of its equator, leading to additional cells by latitude. Mars' Hadley circulation is offset from its equator.<ref>{{cite book|last1=De Pateris|first1=I|last2=Lissauer|first2=J|title=Planetary Sciences|publisher=Cambridge University Press}}</ref> Titan, a far smaller body, likely has one enormous cell, flipping polarity from northerly to southerly with its seasons.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rannou|first1=P|last2=Montmessin|first2=F|title=The latitudinal distribution of clouds on Titan|journal=Science|date=Jan 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ice Cloud Heralds Fall at Titan's South Pole|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/cassini/whycassini/cassini20130411.html|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref>
The [[Atmosphere of Jupiter#Zones, belts, and jets|bands of Jupiter]] are thought to be numerous Hadley-like cells by latitude.
===Storms and cyclonic activity===
The large storms seen on the gas giants are considered analogous to Earth [[Tropical cyclone|cyclones]]. However, this is an imperfect metaphor as expected, due to the large differences in sizes, temperature, and composition between Earth and the gas giants, and even between gas giants.
[[Polar vortex|Polar vortices]] were observed [[Polar vortex#Outside Earth|on Venus and Saturn]]. In turn, Earth's thinner atmosphere shows weaker polar vorticity and effects.
===Lightning and aurorae===
Both [[lightning]] and [[aurorae]] have been observed on other bodies after extensive study at Earth. Lightning has been detected on Venus, and may be a sign of active volcanism on that planet, as [[Dirty thunderstorm|volcanic lightning]] is known on Earth.<ref>{{cite web|title=EVIDENCE FOR LIGHTNING ON VENUS|url=http://www-ssc.igpp.ucla.edu/personnel/russell/papers/evidence/|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Lightning Strikes Venus|url=http://blogs.agu.org/geospace/2014/12/19/lightning-strikes-venus/|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref> Aurorae have been observed on Jupiter and its moon Ganymede.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sp.ph.ic.ac.uk/~mgaland/ihy/Comparative_Planetary_Auroralogy_v4.pdf |title=Comparative Planetary Auroralogy |accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref>
===Comparative climatology===
An understanding of the evolutionary histories and current states of the Venus and Mars climates is directly relevant for studies of the past, present and future climates of Earth.<ref>{{cite web | title=Decadal Survey: Comparative Climatology White Paper | url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/decadal/vexag/ComparativeClimateWhitePaperV3.pdf | accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref>
==Hydrology== {{main|Hydrology}}
A growing number of bodies display relict or current hydrological modification. Earth, the "ocean planet," is the prime example. Other bodies display lesser modifications, indicating their similarities and differences. This may be defined to include fluids other than water, such as light hydrocarbons on Titan, or possibly supercritical carbon dioxide on Mars, which do not persist in Earth conditions. Ancient lava flows in turn may be considered a form of hydrological modification, which may be confounded with other fluids.<ref>{{ cite journal|last=Leverington|first=D.|title=A volcanic origin for the outflow channels of Mars: Key evidence and major implications |journal=Geomorphology |volume=132 |issue=3–4 |pages=51–75 |date=Sep 2011 |doi=10.1016/j.geomorph.2011.05.022|bibcode = 2011Geomo.132...51L }}</ref> Io currently has lava calderas and lakes. Fluid modification may have occurred on bodies as small as Vesta;<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Scully |first1=J. |last2=Russell |first2=C. |title=Geomorphological evidence for transient water flow on Vesta |journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters |volume=411 |date=1 Feb 2015|display-authors=etal |doi=10.1016/j.epsl.2014.12.004 |bibcode=2015E&PSL.411..151S |pages=151–163}}</ref> hydration in general has been observed.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=De Sanctis|first1=M.|last2=Combe|first2=J.|last3=Ammanito|first3=E.|last4=Palomba|first4=E.|last5=Longobardo|first5=A.|last6=McCord|first6=T.|last7=Marchi|first7=S.|last8=Capaccioni|first8=F.|last9=Capria|first9=M.|title=Detection of Widespread Hydrated Materials on Vesta by the VIR Imaging Spectrometer on board the Dawn Mission|journal=Astrophysical Journal Letters|date=3 Oct 2012|volume=758|issue=2|display-authors=etal|doi=10.1088/2041-8205/758/2/l36|pages=L36|bibcode = 2012ApJ...758L..36D }}</ref>
If fluids include [[Hydrogeology|groundwater]] and [[Water vapor|vapor]], the [[Extraterrestrial liquid water|list of bodies with hydrological modification]] includes Earth, Mars, and Enceladus, to a lesser extent comets and some asteroids, likely Europa and Triton, and possibly Ceres, Titan, and Pluto. Venus may have had hydrology in its early history, which would since have been [[Crustal recycling|erased]].
Fluid modification and mineral deposition on Mars, as observed by the MER and MSL rovers, is studied in light of Earth features and minerals.<ref>{{cite web |title=Duststone on Mars: source, transport, deposition, and erosion |url=https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/70044189 |accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref> Minerals observed from orbiters and landers indicates formation in aqueous conditions;<ref>{{cite news|title=NASA's Curiosity Mars Rover Finds Mineral Match|url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4361|work=NASA/JPL|date=November 4, 2014}}</ref> morphologies indicate fluid action and deposition.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Arvidson |first1=R. |last2=Squyres |first2=S. |title=Ancient Aqueous Environments at Endeavour Crater, Mars |journal=Science |volume=343 |issue=6169 |date=24 Jan 2014 |doi=10.1126/science.1248097|bibcode = 2014Sci...343G.386A |display-authors=etal |pages=1248097 |pmid=24458648}}</ref>
Extant Mars hydrology includes [[Seasonal flows on warm Martian slopes|brief, seasonal flows on slopes]]; however, most Martian water is frozen into its polar caps and subsurface, as indicated by [[MARSIS|ground penetrating radars]] and [[pedestal craters]].<ref>{{ cite journal|last1=Kadish|first1=S.|last2=Barlow|first2=N.|title=Pedestal Crater Distribution and Implications for a New Model of Formation|date=Jan 2006 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kadish |first1=S. |last2=Head |title=Martian pedestal craters: Marginal sublimation pits implicate a climate-related formation mechanism |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=35 |issue=16 |date=Aug 2008 |doi=10.1029/2008gl034990 |bibcode=2008GeoRL..3516104K}}</ref> [[Freezing point depression|Antifreeze mixtures]] such as salts, peroxides, and perchlorates may allow fluid flow at Martian temperatures.
Analogues of Mars landforms on Earth include Siberian and Hawaiian valleys, Greenland slopes, the Columbian Plateau, and various [[Sink (geography)|playas]]. Analogues for human expeditions (e.g. geology and hydrology fieldwork) include Devon Island, Canada, Antarctica, Utah, the Euro-Mars project, and Arkaroola, South Australia.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Chapman |first1=M. |title=The Geology of Mars: Evidence from Earth-Based Analogs |publisher=Cambridge University Press |date=2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Mars Analog Research |editor1-last=Clarke |editor1-first=J. |publisher=The Astronautical Society}}</ref>
The Moon, on the other hand, is a natural laboratory for regolith processes and weathering on anhydrous airless bodies- modification and alteration by meteoroid and micrometeoroid impacts, the implantation of solar and interstellar charged particles, radiation damage, spallation, exposure to ultraviolet radiation, and so on. Knowledge of the processes that create and modify the lunar regolith is essential to understanding the compositional and structural attributes of other airless planet and asteroid regoliths.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Scientific Context for Exploration of the Moon |author=National Research Council |date=2007}}</ref>
Other possibilities include extrasolar planets completely [[Ocean planet|covered by oceans]], which would lack some Earthly processes.
{{see also|Extraterrestrial liquid water|Water on Mars}}
==Dynamics== {{main|Celestial mechanics}}
Earth, alone among terrestrial planets, possesses a large moon. This is thought to confer stability to Earth's axial tilt, and thus seasons and climates. The closest analogue is the Pluto-Charon system, though its axial tilt is completely different. Both our Moon and Charon are hypothesized to have formed via [[Giant impact hypothesis|giant impacts]].
Giant impacts are hypothesized to account for both the tilt of Uranus, and the retrograde rotation of Venus. Giant impacts are also candidates for the Mars ocean hypothesis, and the high density of Mercury.
Most giant planets ([[Moons of Neptune|except Neptune]]) have retinues of moons, rings, ring shepherds, and moon Trojans analogous to mini-solar systems. These systems are postulated to have accreted from analogous gas clouds, and possibly with analogous migrations during their formation periods. The Cassini mission was defended on the grounds that Saturn system dynamics would contribute to studies of Solar System dynamics and formation.
Studies of ring systems inform us of many-body dynamics. This is applicable to the asteroid and Kuiper Belts, and the early Solar System, which had more objects, dust, and gas. It is relevant to the magnetospherics of those bodies. It is also relevant to the dynamics of our galaxy and others. In turn, though the [[Rings of Saturn|Saturnian system]] is readily studied (by [[Cassini mission|Cassini]], ground telescopes, and space telescopes), the simpler and lower mass ring systems of the other giants makes their explanations somewhat easier to fathom. The Jupiter ring system is perhaps more completely understood at present than any of the other three.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Miner|first1=E.|last2=Wessen|first2=R.|last3=Cuzzi|first3=J.|title=Planetary Ring Systems|publisher=Springer-Praxis|date=2007}}</ref>
[[Asteroid families]] and [[Kirkwood gap|gaps]] indicate their local dynamics. They are in turn indicative of the Kuiper Belt, and its hypothesized Kuiper cliff. The Hildas and Jupiter Trojans are then relevant to the Neptune Trojans and Plutinos, Twotinos, etc.
Neptune's relative lack of a moon system suggests its formation and dynamics. The migration of Triton explains the ejection or destruction of competing moons, analogous to Hot Jupiters (also in sparse systems), and the Grand Tack hypothesis of Jupiter itself, on a smaller scale.
The planets are considered to have formed by accretion of larger and larger particles, into asteroids and planetesimals, and into today's bodies. Vesta and Ceres are hypothesized to be the only surviving examples of planetesimals, and thus samples of the formative period of the Solar System.
[[Planetary transit|Transits]] of Mercury and Venus have been observed as analogues of extrasolar transits. As Mercury and Venus transits are far closer and thus appear "deeper," they can be studied in far finer detail. Similarly, analogues to our asteroid and Kuiper belts have been observed around other star systems, though in far less detail.
{{see also|Formation and evolution of the Solar System|Numerical model of the Solar System}}
==Astrobiology== {{main|Astrobiology}}
Earth is the only body known to contain life; this results in geologic and atmospheric life signatures apart from the organisms themselves. [[Atmosphere of Mars#Methane|Methane observed on Mars]] has been postulated but cannot be definitively ascribed as a [[biosignature]]. Multiple processes of non-biological methane generation are seen on Earth as well.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Müntener|first1=Othmar|title=Serpentine and serpentinization: A link between planet formation and life|url=http://geology.gsapubs.org/content/38/10/959.full|website=The Geological Society of America}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Velbel|first1=M|title=Weathering of olivine and pyroxene on Mars: Evidence from missions, meteorites, and terrestrial mineral analogs, in American Geophysical Union, Fall Meeting 2010|date=Dec 2010|publisher=American Geophysical Union}}</ref>
The detection of biomarkers or biosignatures on other worlds is an active area of research.<ref>{{cite web|title=Biosignatures of Fe-oxidizing microbes|url=http://www.ceoe.udel.edu/our-people/profiles/cschan/biosignatures-of-fe-oxidizing-microbes|website=University of Delaware|accessdate=17 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519205846/http://www.ceoe.udel.edu/our-people/profiles/cschan/biosignatures-of-fe-oxidizing-microbes|archivedate=19 May 2015|df=}}</ref> Although oxygen and/or ozone are generally considered strong signs of life, these too have alternate, non-biological explanations.<ref>{{cite web | title=NASA's New Carbon Observatory Will Help Us Understand Alien Worlds | url=http://www.astrobio.net/news-exclusive/nasas-new-carbon-observatory-will-help-us-understand-alien-worlds/ | accessdate=26 April 2015 }}</ref>
The Galileo mission, while performing a gravity assist flyby of Earth, treated our planet as an extraterrestrial one, in a test of life detection techniques. Conversely, the Deep Impact mission's High Resolution Imager, intended for examining comets starting from great distances, could be repurposed for exoplanet observations in its EPOXI extended mission.
Conversely, detection of life entails identification of those processes favoring or preventing life. This occurs primarily via study of Earth life and Earth processes,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lim |first1=D. |title=Pavilion Lake Research Project |url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/abscicon2010/pdf/5497.pdf |website=Lunar and Planetary Institute |accessdate=17 May 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref> though this is in effect a sample size of one. Care must be taken to avoid observation and selection biases. Astrobiologists consider alternative chemistries for life, and study on Earth [[Extremophile|extremophile organisms]] that expand the potential definitions of habitable worlds.

revision.text:
'''D-type asteroids''' have a very low [[albedo]] and a featureless reddish [[Asteroid spectral types|spectrum]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} It has been suggested that they have a composition of organic-rich [[silicate]]s, [[carbon]] and [[anhydrous]] silicates, possibly with water [[ice]] in their interiors.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} D-type asteroids are found in the outer [[asteroid belt]] and beyond; examples are [[152 Atala]], and [[944 Hidalgo]] as well as the majority of [[Jupiter Trojan|Jupiter trojans]]. It has been suggested that the [[Tagish Lake (meteorite)|Tagish Lake meteorite]] was a fragment from a D-type asteroid, and that the Martian moon [[Phobos (moon)|Phobos]] is closely related. The [[Nice model]] suggests that D-type asteroids may have originated in the [[Kuiper belt]]. 46 D-type asteroids are known, including [[3552 Don Quixote]], [[944 Hidalgo]], [[624 Hektor]], and [[10199 Chariklo]]. == Examples == A list of some of the largest D-type asteroids. {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! rowspan=2 | Name of Asteroid ! colspan=2 |Classification ! rowspan=2 | Diameter
(km) ! rowspan=2 | Diameter
